In Quarto text, you may use LaTeX mathematical notation in sections delimited by `$ ... $` to show up inline, or by `$$ ... $$` to show up as a separate paragraph. Here are basics:

|           LaTeX            |           Result           |
|:--------------------------:|:--------------------------:|
|           `x^y`            |           $x^y$            |
|           `x_y`            |           $x_y$            |
|   `\alpha, \mu, \sigma`    |   $\alpha, \mu, \sigma$    |
|          `\bar x`          |          $\bar x$          |
|          `\hat x`          |          $\hat x$          |
|         `\sqrt{x}`         |         $\sqrt{x}$         |
|       `\frac{x}{y}`        |       $\frac{x}{y}$        |
|       `(\frac{x}{y}`       |      $(\frac{x}{y})$       |
| `\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)` | $\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)$ |

e.g.

```         
$$
\bar{x} \pm z^* \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}
$$ 
```

gives $$
\bar{x} \pm z^* \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}
$$

and

```         
$$
z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}}
$$ 
```

gives $$
z = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{\sigma / \sqrt{n}}
$$

To learn more about Latex, see http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/LaTeX.
